text.tspan: MGT 325 Fall 2009
Dr. Jonelle Roth Tuesdays and Thursdays
TA: Gordon Schmidt 2:40-4:00 PM 102 Conrad Hall
E-mail: roth@bus.msu.edu .
Office: N421 North Business Complex
Office Hours: Thurs. 10 – 11:30 AM, or by appointment
MANAGEMENT SKILLS
MGT 325 is an introductory course intended to help students develop management skills
based on key concepts, models, and theories of management and organizational behavior.
The topic of “Organizational Behavior” encompasses team performance, leadership, role
structure, conflict, motivation and a host of other issues that drive the effectiveness and
ultimately the performance of individuals, teams, and ultimately organizations. It
encompasses team performance, leadership, role structure, conflict, motivation and a
host of other issues that drive the effectiveness and ultimately the performance of
individuals, teams, and ultimately organizations. A combination of readings, lectures,
discussion, and videos will be used to try to convey these points.
Colquitt, J.A., LePine, J.A., and Wesson, M.J. (2009). Organizational Behavior: Improving
Performance and Commitment in the Workplace. Boston, MA: McGraw-Hill Irwin.
Online option:
Colquitt, Jason; Wesson, Michael; LePine, Jeffrey, Organizational Behavior: Improving
Performance and Commitment in Workplace, 1st Edition,
http://www.coursesmart.com/givecoursesmartatry?xmlid=0077271580&__instructor=1112
Course Policy
1. Attendance at lectures is important. This form of instruction is necessary in an introy
course. Lectures are a very efficient means of communicating information basic informa,
updated information and real-world examples. Lectures will be derived from the assigned
textbook, personal experiences and other sources. Dr. Roth will NOT “teach the text.”
focus on key concepts and introduce "real world" examples. Lecture notes will be available
the course website. However, these notes will summarize the main points made in classe
not sufficient, by themselves, to ensure a high score on the exams. They are provided
taking aid, but are not meant to replace note-taking during class. In other words, many
will be said in class that do not appear in the PowerPoint slides or in the textbook, but may
